column4: ok, question.. anyone know what "/bin/bash/A" is suppose to be?
/bin/bash is a directory on your system? weird...
my error is "/bin/bash: A: command not found"
ah.. something is trying to run a command using bash.. the command being "A" and bash responds that there is no such command
what are you trying to run when you get this error?
i'm trying to run A arm -T multi -C none -n "CWM tenderloin Multiboot" -d out/target/product/tenderloin/kernel: out/target/product/tenderloin/recovery.img
my immediate guess would be a script used with filename containing spaces
I'm guessing you got that off some webpage or readme file, right?
in the output of trying to compile an android kernel
sure the A is supposed to be there?
almost 100% sure
but you're not typing that in yourself? it's from the output of some kind of make/automake/configure script?
yes. it's in a makefile

ok, I've got a vague guess here..   the script might look something like this    $SOMEVARIABLE -A arm ..... and $SOMEVARIABLE is supposed to be a program of some kind needed for compiling this.. but for some reason this variable is empty and it then tries to run -A arm and so on
that might be possible!
check if you've got all the required packages installed.. there might be something missing
from google I found something that looks like this $MKIMAGE -A arm -T multi -C none -n 'test-multi-image' -d    $MKIMAGE might be a tool to create an image-file
i remember MKIMAGE for something else...
i found the file that uses the -A
great, did you find some way of fixing it?
i found the issue :D i just defined the path to MKIMAGE in the source that required it heh
ah.. nice =)
odd that the configuration scripts didn't do that automagically..
you're welcome
